contentrichtext.text: {{In-universe| subject = a [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Forgotten Realms|Dungeons & Dragons role-playing game]]| described_object = a fictional demi-god| category = |date=December 2011}} {{Forgotten Realms Deity|fgcolor=#fff| image=| bgcolor=#000| fgcolor=#fff| name=Iyachtu Xvim| title=The Godson, The Son of Bane, The New Darkness| home=Bastion of Hate ([[Gehenna (Dungeons & Dragons)|Gehenna]], Chamada)| power=Lesser| alignment=Lawful Evil| portfolio=Fear, Hatred, Tyranny| alias=None| super=Bane| }} In the [[Forgotten Realms]] [[campaign setting]] for the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' [[fantasy]] [[role-playing game]], '''Iyachtu Xvim''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|iː|j|ə|x|t|uː|_|z|ə|ˈ|v|ɪ|m}} {{respell|EE|yəkh-too}} {{respell|z(ə)|VIM|'}})<ref name="FRCS1E"/> was the half-demonic son of the god [[Bane (Forgotten Realms)|Bane]] and temporary holder of his portfolio. Iyachtu Xvim was a [[Lawful Evil]] lesser [[deity]]. ==Publication history== ===Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st edition (1977-1988)=== Iyachtu Xvim was first described in the ''Forgotten Realms Campaign Set'''s "Cyclopedia of the Realms" booklet (1987), which states that he "is called "the Godson" and the son of Bane, and serves as Bane's instrument in the Realms, directly carrying out his "father's" will".<ref name="FRCS1E">{{cite book | isbn =0-88038-472-7 | title = Forgotten Realms Campaign Set | author = Ed Greenwood, [[Jeff Grubb]] and Karen S. Martin | year = 1987 | publisher = [[TSR, Inc.]]}}</ref> ===Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition (1989-1999)=== Iyachtu Xvim is fully detailed in ''[[Faiths & Avatars]]'' (1996),<ref name="F&A">Martin, Julia, and Eric L Boyd. ''[[Faiths & Avatars]]'' (TSR, 1996)</ref> and his clergy is further described in ''[[Warriors and Priests of the Realms]]'' (1996).<ref>Terra, John. ''[[Warriors and Priests of the Realms]]'' ([[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], 1996)</ref> His role in the cosmology of the [[Planescape]] campaign setting was described in ''[[On Hallowed Ground]]'' (1996).<ref>McComb, Colin. ''[[On Hallowed Ground]]'' ([[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], 1996)</ref> His relationships with the nonhuman deities in the Forgotten Realms was covered in ''[[Demihuman Deities]]'' (1998).<ref>Boyd, Eric L. ''[[Demihuman Deities]]'' ([[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], 1998)</ref> ===Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition (2000-2007)=== Iyachtu Xvim's demise is described in the ''Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting'' (2001).<ref>{{cite book | title = Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting | author = Ed Greenwood et al. | year = 2001 | publisher = Wizard of the Coast | isbn = 0-7869-1836-5 }}</ref> ==History== During the [[Time of Troubles (Forgotten Realms)|Time of Troubles]], the then-[[demigod]] Xvim was imprisoned within the depths of [[Zhentil Keep]]. After the end of the Time of Troubles and his father's demise, Iyachtu Xvim was granted his father's command of [[hatred]], and [[tyranny]], and elevated to godhood. For little over a decade, Xvim reigned as a minor god, a feeble successor to his fearsome sire. During his existence, Xvim was petty, power-hungry, and ruthless, in some ways like his father. However, he was not nearly as strong, especially in comparison with the other "new" deity in the [[List of Forgotten Realms deities|Faerûnian Pantheon]], [[Cyric]]. In ''Tymora's Luck'', Xvim impersonated [[Sirrion]] in a bid to seize the portfolios of [[Tymora]] and [[Beshaba]], when [[Lathander]] attempted to re-create [[Tyche]] by reuniting the two goddesses. (Tyche became Tymora and Beshaba after becoming corrupted by [[Moander]] during the Dawn Cataclysm.) His plan was foiled by [[Finder Wyvernspur]] and his priest Joel, who threw the two halves of the Finder's Stone into the fusion chamber. Xvim fled, but his realm, the Bastion of Hate, was already destroyed by [[Beshaba]].<ref>[[Kate Novak]] & [[Jeff Grubb]], ''Tymora's Luck'' (TSR, 1997)</ref> Then, on [[Midwinter]] night of 1372 DR, the young god was consumed by a blazing green fire, from which emerged a resurrected Bane. Nearly all former clerics of Xvim (who in turn shifted to his allegiance after the death of his father) repledged themselves to the Church of Bane. Xvim is now considered a dead god, and for as long as his father holds on to divinity, he will probably remain as such. ==References== {{reflist}} {{D&D deities}} [[Category:Dead Dungeons & Dragons deities]] [[Category:Forgotten Realms deities]]
